editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Bloody banquet.

Drue, Thomas, fl. 1616-1653,

note.p: Sometimes attributed to Thomas Drue, to Thomas Barker, to Robert Davenport, and to Thomas Dekker and Thomas Middleton.
Running title reads: The bloody banquet.
Reproduction of the original in the University of Michigan. Library.

quote.l: Hector adest secumque deos in proelia ducit

list.item: Fidelio. Two faithful servants to the Lydian King.
Amorpho two faithful servants to the Lydian King.
Sextorio. Two unfaithful servants of his.
Lodovicus. Two unfaithful servants of his.

div.stage: At one door the old King of Lydia, tymethes his son, Lapyrus his nephew, and soldiers. At the other the old King of Lycia, Zantippus his son, Eurymone his daughter, and soldiers. The two King's parley, and change hostages for peace. Lapyrus is given to the Lycian, and Zantippus to the Lydian. The Lycian seems to offer his daughter Eurymone to Lapyrus to fall from his uncle, and join with him; he accepts her, drawing his sword against his country and uncle the Lydian sends his son tymethes for aid; he enters again with Armatrites King of Cilicia, Zenarchus his son, and Mazeres a young prince, the cilician Kings follower. All they draw against the Lycians party, whereat they all with Lapyrus fly; the two other Kings pursuing them. Then enter the old Queen of Lydia flying from her nephew Lapyrus, with two babes in her arms; he pursuing her with his drawn sword.
div.l: After the waste of many thousand wounds
Given and received alike, in seven set battles,
Lydia's old King upon conditions signed
For peace and truce, entered on feigned league
With his fierce enemy the Lycian King
Gave him in hostage as his pledge of faith,
His nephew, lord lapyrus, and received
Noble Zantippus from the Lycian;
To make the contract full and honourable,
This lord lapyrus entertained and welcomed
But chiefly by the fair Eurymone
The King's sole daughter, who unto lapyrus
Offers her as his bride, so he would turn
A traitor to his country and his King:
Lapyrus, to obtain the beauteous maid
Turns traitor to his King, and joins his force
Unto his fair love's fathers, Lycia's King ▪
Th' old King of Lydia being so beset
By his own nephews unexpected treacheries,
Sent forth his son tymethes to crave aid
From Armatrites King of great Cilicia,
Which he obtained in a disastrous hour
As the event will witness; in this trouble
The frighted Queen with her two infants fled
Into a forest, fearing the sad ruin
Hourly expected, until Armatrites
With a fresh army forced lapyrus fly
And saved the King, doomed for worse treachery.
What follows shows itself; 'tis our full due,
If we with labour give content to you. Exit.

div.head: Scene. 1.
div.stage: Enter, the two Kings of Lydia and Cilicia, Zenarchus' son to the cilician, Tymethes, son to the Lydian, Mazeres, Fidelio, Amorpho, Sextorio, Lodovicus, when they come unto the throne, the tyrant of Cilicia puts by the old King, and ascends alone: all snatch out their swords, Mazeres crowns him, the old King and Tymethes stand amazed.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Speranza.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Long live Armatrites King of Lydia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Art thou amazed old King, and all thy people
Mutually labouring in a fit of wonder?
Start from those palē dreams, we will prove all true,
Who wins the day the brightness is his due.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: King of Cilicia.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I and Lydia now,
Bate us not our titles, we and ours
Have sweat and dear earned them in our flesh.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It savours not of nobleness nor virtue,
Religion, loyalty, heaven or natures laws
So most perfidiously to enter, tyrant,
Where was, expected honesty and honour,
Assistance from a friend, not a dissembler,
A royal neighbour and no politic foe.
What worse than this could th' enemy perform?
And when shines friendship best but in a storm?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Why, doting Lydia, is it of no virtue
To bring our army hither and put in venture
Our person and their lives upon our foes?
Wasting our courage, weakening our best forces;
Impoverishing the heart of our munition,
And having won the honour of the battle
To throw our glory on unworthy spirits,
And so unload victories honey thighs
To let drones seed?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Will nothing satisfy but all?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Without all, nothing.
The kingdom and not under suits our blood,
Flies ate are not eagles preys nor thanks our food:
And for Cilicia our other sphere,
Our son Zenarchus let thy beams move there.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Rather, my lord, let me move pity here,
Unto that reverend fate-afflict King;
For whom, with his disconsolate son (My friend
And plighted brother) I here kneel as suitor.
O my most noble father, still retain
The seal of honour and religion,
A kingdom rightly possessed by course,
Contains more joy than is usurped by force.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: The boy hath almost changed us.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: He cools — my lord, remember you are possessed.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: What, with the devil?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: The devil! the dukedom, the kingdom, Lydia.
All pant under your sceptre; the sway's yours,
Be not bought out with words, a kingdom's dear,
Kiss fortune, keep your mind, and keep your state,
You're laughed at if you prove compassionate.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Thanks to Mazeres, he hath refreshed our spirits,
Zenarchus, 'tis thy death if thou proceed,
Thy words we threat, rise silent or else bleed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who can expect but blood where tyrants govern?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: We are not yet so cruel to thy fortune
As was lapyrus, thy own nephew, treacherous;
That stole upon thy life, besieged thee basely,
And had betrayed thee to thine enemy's anger
Had we not beat his strength to his own throat;
And made him shrink before us, all can tell
In him 'twas monstrous, 'tis in us but well;
A trick of war, advantage, policy, nay rather recompense;
There's more deceit in peace, 'tis common there
To unfold young heirs, the old may well stand bare.
You have your life, be thankful, and 'tis more
Than your perfidious nephew would consent to,
had he surprised you first, your fate is cast,
The sooner you be gone 'twill prove the safer.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: On thee lapyrus, and thy treacheries, fall
The heavy burden of an old man's curse.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Your Queen with her two infants fled the city
Affrighted at this treason and new wars.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: News of more sadnesses than the kingdom's loss,
She fled upon her hour, for had she stayed
She had either died, been banished, or betrayed.
I have some servants here?

sp.speaker: Arma.
sp.l: All these my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: All these? not all ▪ you did forget, I am not worth the flattering, I am donē,
Old and at set, honour the rising sun.
If any for love serve me, which is he?
Now let him shame the world and follow me.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: That's I my lord.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What two of you?
Let it be enrolled
Two follow a King when he is poorē and old. Exit cum suis.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.l: Farewell King. I'll play the flounder, keep me to my tide.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And so will I, this is the flowing side.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Those men are yours, my lord.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: We'll grace them chiefly,
Wait for employment, place and eminence,
The like to each that to our bounty flies,
For he that falls to us shall surely rise.
His son tymethes little frights our thoughts,
He's young, and given to pleasure, not to plots.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Your grace defines him right, he may remain,
The prince your son, binds him in a love-chain;
There's little fear of him.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Their loves are dear,
Base boy, he leaves his father to live here.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: His presence sets a gloss on your attempts,
They have their luster from him.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: He's their countenance,
'Twas well observed and followed, he shall stay,
Mazeres, thou armest us that won the day ▪

div.stage: Exit, all but Zenarchus and Tymethes.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: None but Mazeres, that court fly, could on
The virtues of the King blow such corruption,
Man falls to vice in minutes, runs, and leaps,
But unto goodness he takes wary steps.
How soon a tyrant? why Tymethes, friend, brother?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Peace, prithee peace, you undo me if you wake me,
I hope I'm in a dream.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Would 'twere so happy?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: No! why then wake beggar; but the comfort is
I have brave seeming kinsmen: why Zenarchus,
'Tis not the loss of kingdom, father's banishment,
Uncertainty of mother, afflicts me
With half the violence that those crossed affections,
Betwixt your princely sister and ourself,
Who upon fortune, or her father's frown,
Erecting the whole fabric of her love,
Either now will not, or else dare not love me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Chance alters not affection, see in me
That hold thee dear still spite of tyranny:
Fate does but dim the glass of a right man,
He still retains his worth, do what fate can.
Change faith for dross? I will not call her sister,
That shall hate virtue for affliction.
And here she comes to clear those doubts herself.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Strange alteration! will the King my father
Go to his grave a ruffian and a treacher?
In his grey heirs turn tyrant to his friends?
Wasting his penitential times in plots,
Acting more sins than he hath tears to weep for them?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Alas lady, fortune hath changed my state, can you love a beggar?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why fortune hath the least command o'er love,
She cannot drive Tymethes from himself,
And 'tis Tymethes, not his painted glories,
My soul in her accomplished wish desires.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What say you now sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Nothing but admire
That heaven can frame a creature like a woman
And she be constant, seeing most are common.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Put by your wonder sir, she proves the same,
I spoke her virtues for her ere she came,
And when my father dies I here do vow,
This kingdom now detained wrongfully
Shall then return unforcedly to you,
In part thy dowry, but in all thy due.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Unmatched honest young man.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Comen, let your lips meet though your fortunes wander.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Ha! taste lips so bounteously with a beggar?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Thus in firm state let your affection's rest,
Time, that makes wretched, makes the same men blessed. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: What's here? either the princes out of charity's rareness
Are pleased to lay aside their glories, and refresh
The gasping fortunes of a desperate wretch;
Or if for larger bounties I was mad
To advise the King for his remaining here
That had been banished, and with him my fear:
I love the Princess, and the King allows it,
If he should prove a rival to my love,
I have argued fair for his abiding here:
My plots shall work his ruin, if one fail
I'll raise a second, for I must prevail:
I that used policy to cause him stay
Can show like art to rid my fears away. Exit.

div.head: Scene. 2.
div.stage: Enter the old Queen with two babes, as being hard pursued.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O whither shall I fly with these poor babēs?
Twice set upon by thieves within this forest
Who robbed me of my clothes, and left me these,
Which better suit with my calamity:
what fate pursues the good old King my husband,
I cannot learn which is my worst affliction;
O treacherous Lapirus! impious nephew!
All horrors of a guilty breast keep with thee;
Either poor babes, you must pine here for food,
Or have the wars drink your immaculate blood.
O flyen, least life and honour be betrayed. Exit.

div.head: Scen. 3.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Villain and fugitive, where wilt thou hide
Th' abhorred burden of thy wretched flesh?
In what disguise canst thou be safe and free,
Having betrayed thy country? base Lapirus.
Earth stretch thy throat, take down this bitter pill,
Loathing the hateful taste of his own ill.

div.stage: Enter the Queen and two soldiers pursuing her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O help, good heaven save a poor wretch from slaughter.

sp.speaker: The. 1.
sp.l: Stop her mouth first, soldiers must have their sport
'Tis dear earned, they venture their blood for't.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: A mother so enforced by pitiless slaves?
Let me redeem my honour in her rescue,
And in this deed my former baseness die.

sp.speaker: The. 2.
sp.l: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: If ever woman bore you.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Who ere bore them monsters begotten them; merciless damned villains.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Hold, hold, sir; we are soldiers, but do not love to fight. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Let me dissuade you from all hope of recompense
Save thanks and prayers, which are the beggars gifts,

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You cannot give me that I have more need of
Than prayers; for my soul hath a poor stock;
There's a fair house within, but 'tis ill furnished
There wants true tears for hanging ▪ penitent falls,
for without prayers soldiers are but bare walls:
Whence are you? that with such a careful charge,
Dare pass this dangerous forest?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Generous sir,
I was of Lydia once, as happy then
As now unfortunate; till one lapyrus,
That traitorous villain nephew to the King
Sought the confusion of his state and him;
And with a secret army girt his land,
When peace was plighted by his enemy's hand ▪
Little expecting such unnatural treason
From forth a kinsman's bosom; all admired
But I his miserable Queen.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O sink into perdition, let me hear no further,Aside.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I'll tell you all; for your so late attempt
Confirms you honest, and my thoughts so keep you:
I frighted at new wars, and his false breath,
Chose rather with these babes this lingering death.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O in her words I endure a thousand deaths.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: The truth of this sad story hath been yours.
Now, courteous sir, may I request your name,
That in my prayers I may place the same,

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I'll put my death into her woeful hands.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I hear you not sir, I desire you name.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: To add some small content to your distress,
Know that lapyrus, whom your miseries
May rightly curse, and be revenged justly
Lurks in this forest equally distressed.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: In this forest lurks that abhorred villain?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: These eyes did see him; and faith lady, say
If you should meet that worst of villains here,
That treacher, monster; what would you attempt?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: His speedy death, I should forget all mercy,
Had I but means fully to express my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You would not, Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: No? by these infant's tears
That weep for hunger, I would thoroughly do't.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: See yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O wheres?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Here, take my sword,
Are you yet constant? shame your sex and be so; will you do't?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I see him not.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Strike him through his guilt and treachery
And let him see the horrors of his perjured soul,
Are you ready?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Pray let me see him first. Pulls off his false beard and kneels.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: You see him now — now do't.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Lapirus!
O fortunate revenge! now all thy villainies
Shall be at once requited, thy country's ruin
The King thy uncle's sorrow, my own miseries,
Shall at this minute all one vengeance meet.
Alas, he doth submit, prays, and relents,
Who could wish more? none made from woman can,
Small glory 'twere to kill a kneeling man:
When he in penitent sighs his soul commends
Thou sendest him to the gods, thyself to th' fiends:
But harken to thy piteous infant's cries,
And they're for vengeance, peace then, now he dies.
Ingrateful woman, he delivered thee
From ravishment, canst thou his murderess be?
What's riches to thy honours? that rare treasure
Which worlds redeem not, yet 'tis lost at pleasure.
Kill him that preserved that? and in thy rescue
His noble rage so manfully behaved:
Rise, rise, he that repents is ever saved.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Will misery yet a longer life afford;
To see a Queen so poor, not worth her word?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I am better than my word, my word was death ▪

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Man's never past grief, till he be passed his breath.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I pardon all lapyrus.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Do not do't.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: And only to one penance I enjoin thee
For all thy faults past, while we here remain
Within this forest, this thy task shall be,
To procure succour to my babes and me.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: And if I fail may the earth swallow me.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thou'rt now grown good, here could I ever dwell,
Were the old King, my husband safe and well. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene. 4.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Come, come, drive away these fits, faith I'll have thee merry.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: As your son and heir at his father's funeral

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Thou seest my sister constantly affects thee.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: There were no mirth nor music else for me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Sir in this castle the old King my father
O'erworn with jealousy keeps his beauteous wife,
I think thou never sawest her.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Why then thy judgements fresh, I'll visit her
On purpose for thy censure.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I speak my affection.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Nay on my knowledge she's worth jealousy ▪
Though jealousy be far unworthy a King.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: My loved lord?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: How cheers the Queen?They whisper.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Have I not seen this fellow before now?
He has an excellent presence for a pander,
I know not his office.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Use those words to her.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: They shall be used my lord, and any thing
That comes to using, let it come to me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: What's he Zenarchus?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Who Roxano? A fellow in great trust,
Elected by my father's jealousy.
But he, and all the rest attend upon her
I think would turn her panders for reward;
For 'tis not watch nor ward keeps woman chaste,
If honours watch in her mind be not placed.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Right oracle; what gain hath jealousy?
Fruitless suspicion, sighs, ridiculous groans,
Hunger and lust will break through flesh and stonēs:
And like a whirlwind blows ope castle doors.
Italian padlockes,

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What mad lords are your jealous people then,
That locks their wives from all men but their men?
Make them their keepers, to prevent some greater,
So oft it happens to the poors relief,
Keepers eat venison when their lords eat beef.
sp.stage: Enter young Queen with a book in her hand.
sp.l: See, see, she comes.

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.l: Honour of beauty? there man's wishes rise,
Grace and perfection lighten from her eyes.
Amazement is shot through me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: 'Tis Tymethes, lady, Sonnen to the banished King.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Is this he?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: It is sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I never knew the force of a desire
Until this minute struck within my blood;
I fear one look was destined to undo me.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Why tymethes? friend.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: A courtier, and forget your first weapon? go and salute our lady mother.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: He makes towards us: you're prince Tymethes? so I understand.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: The same unfortunate, most gracious lady,
Supremest of your sex in all perfections.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Sir, you're forgetful, this is no place for courtship,
Nor we a subject for't, return to your friend.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: All hopes killed in their blossom.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Too cruelly in faith I put him by,
Wine for our son Zenarchus, 'twas done kindly
You son, and our best visitant.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Duty binds me.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Begin to me Zenarchus, I'll have't so.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Why then there's hope she'll take occasion
To drink to me, she hath no means to avoid it.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I'll prevent all loose thoughts, drink to myself,
sp.stage: Drinks and gives Roxano the Cup.
sp.l: My mind walks yonder, but suspect walks here.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: The devil's on that side and engrosses all,
Smiles, favours, common courtesies, none can fall
But he has a snatch at them; not drink to me?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Make you yond stranger drink. Rox. offers it him.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Pox of't not I.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I speak strange words against my fantasy.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Prithee Tymethes drink.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I am not dry.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I think so too; dry, and so young, 'twere strange,
Come prithee drink to the Queen, my mother.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: You shall rule me — unto that beauteous majesty?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thanks noble sir; I must be wary, my mind's dangerous.
I'll pledge you anon sir. Gives Roxano the cup.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Heart? how contempt ill fortune does pursue?
Not drink, nor pledge, what was she born to do?
I'll stay no longer, lest I get that flame,
Which nothing but cold death can quench or tame.
Zenarchus, come. Exit.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I go, music of mind to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: To you no less.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: And all that you can wish, or I express. Exit.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thanks to our son,
Th' other took leave in silence, but left me
To speak enough both for myself and thee.
Tymethes? that's his name, poor heart take heed,
Look well into th' event ere thou proceed:
Love, yet be wise; impossible, none can;
If ere the wise man claim one foolish hour
'Tis when he loves; he's then in folly's power.
I need not fear the servants that o'erwatch men
Their faiths lie in my coffers, in effect,
More true to me then to my lords suspect.
The fears and dangers that most threaten me,
Live in the party that I must enjoy,
And that's Tymethes; men are apt to boast;
He may in full cups blaze and vaunt himself
unto some meaner mistress; make my shame
The politic engine to beat down her name,
And from thence force a way to the King's ears,
Strange fate; where my love keeps, there keep my fearēs.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Alone? why where's her guard? suffer her alone?
Her thoughts may work, their powers are not her own.
Women have of themselves no entire sway,
Like dial needles they wave every way,
And must be thoroughly taught to be kept right,
And point to none but to their lords delight.
Time to convey and plot? leave her alone!
Why villains — kiss me, my perfection,
This night we'll banquet in these blissful arms.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Your nights are music, and your words are charms.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Kiss me again fair Tethis.

div.stage: Walks off with her, and the guard follows.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: My lady is scarce perfect in her thoughts
Howe'er she framed a smile upon the tyrant.
I have some skill in faces, and yet they never were more deceitful;
A man can scarce know a bawd from a midwife by the face;
An hypocritical Puritan from a devout christian
If you go by the face; well all's not straight in my lady.
She hath certain crooked cogitations if a man had the liberty to search 'em:
If ought point at my advice or performance, she may fortunately
Disclose it: she knows my mettle, and what it yields to an ounce,
She cannot be deceived in't: here's service, and secrecy, and no lady can
Wish more, beside a monkey; she is assured of our faculties, there's none
Of us all that stand her smock sentinels, but would venture a joint
To do her any pleasurable service, and I think that's as much
As any woman desires — mass here she comes.
'tis so me strange physic I know by the working.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: It cannot be kept down with any argument,
'Tis of aspiring force; sparks fly not downward,
No more this received fancy of Tymethes,
I threaten it with my lord's jealousy,
Yet still it rises against all objections;
I see my dangers, in what fears I dwell
There's but a plank on which I run to hell,
Yet were't thrice narrower I should venture on,
None dares do more for sin than woman can.
Misery of love — Roxano? I am observed,
What news Roxano?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: None that's good, madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: No? which is the bad!

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: The worst of all is, madam, you are sad.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Indeed I am not merry.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Would I knew the means would make you so,
I would turn myself into any shape or office
To be the author of it, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Troth I have that hope of thee, I think thou wouldst

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Think it? sfoot, you might swear safely in that action
And never hurt your oath — I ne'er failed yet.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: 'Twere sin to injure thee, I know thou didst not.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Nay I know I did not.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: But my trusty servant,
This plot requires art, secrecy and wit,
Yet out of all can hardly work one safety.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Not one, that's strange, I would 'twere put to me,
I'll make it arrive safe whate'er it be.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thou couldst not my Roxano — why admit I love, now I come to thee.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Admit you love? why all's safe enough yet.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Ay, but a stranger.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Nay, now we are all spoilt lady,
I may look for my brains in my boots — now you have put
Home to me indeed, madam; a stranger? there's a hundred
Deaths in the very name, besides vantage.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I said I should affright thee.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Faith no fool can fright me, madam, commonly called a stranger.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Hast thou the will? or dar'st thou do me good?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Do thee good, sweet lady? as far as I am able ne'er doubt it;
Let me but cast about for safety, and I'll do any thing, madam,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Ay, ay, our safeties; which are mere impossibles,
Love forgets all things but its proper objects.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: What is he? and his name?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Tymethes, in a most unlucky minute
Led hither by our son in law Zenarchus.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Hum, is that the most fortunate, spider catching, smock wrapt gentleman?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Yet if he know me.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: And is it possible a man should lie with a woman and yet not know her?
And yet 'tis possible too — thank my invention, follow that game still.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: He must not know me; than I love no further;
Although for not enjoying him I die;
My lords pale jealousy does so o'erlook me,
That if Tymethes know what he enjoys
It may make way unto my lords mistrust;
Then since in my desire such horrors move
I'll die no other than the death of love.

div.stage: She swounds and Roxano holds her in his arms.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Lady, madam, do you hear?
Have you leisure to swoon now, when I have taken such pains i' th' business?
To take order for your safety, set all things right; why madam?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What says the man?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Why he says like a gentleman every inch of him,
And will perform the office of a gentleman; bring you together;
Put you together, and leave you together: what gentleman can do more?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: And all this safely?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: And all this safely? I by this hand will I,
Or else would I might never do any thing to purpose;
If he have but the first part of a young gentleman in him.
'Tis granted madam; I have crotchets in my brain
That you shall see him and enjoy him, and he not know where he is, nor who it is.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: How? shall he not know me?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Why 'tis the least part of my meaning he should lady.
Do you think you could possibly be safe and he know you?
Why some of your young gallants are of that vainglorious and preposterous
Humour, that if they lay with their own sisters you should hear them prate of't,
This is too usual, there's no wonder in't: what I have said
I will swear to perform, you shall enjoy him ere night
And he not know you next morning.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thou art not only necessary but pleasing,
There, catch our bounty, manage all but right,
As now with gold, with honours we'll requite. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: I am your creature lady; pretty gold,
And by this light methinks most easily earned,
There's no faculty, say I like a pander, and that makes so many
Now adays die in the trade: I have your gold lady,
And eke your service; I am one step higher,
This office makes a gentleman a squire. Exit.

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.l: Come fellow Coridon, are the pits digged?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ay, and as deep as an usurer's conscience I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Shep. 2.
sp.l: Mas and that's deep enough, 'twill devour a widow and three orphans
At a breakfast; soft, is this it?

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.l: Ay, ay, this is it.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Nay for the deepness I'll be sworn; but come my masters and lay these boughs cross over: so, so, artificially, and may all those whoreson mutton-mongers the wolves, hole here, which eat our sheep.

sp.speaker: Shep. 2.
sp.l: I wonder what wolves those are which eat our sheep,
Whether they be he wolves or she wolves?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: They should be he wolves by their loving mutton,
But by their greediness they should be she wolves.
For the belly of a she wolf is never satisfied till it be damned up.

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.p: Why are the she wolves worse than the he's?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why, is not the dam worse than the devil pray?

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.p: You have answered me there indeed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why man, if all the earth were parchment, the sea ink every stick a pen, and every knave a scrivener, they were not all able to write down the knaveries of she wolves.

sp.speaker: Shep. 2.
sp.p: A murrain on them, he's or she's, they sucked the blood of none but our lambs.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O always the weakest goes to the wall, as for example, knock down a sheep and he tumbles forwards, knock down a woman and she tumbles backwards.

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.p: Sirrah, I wonder how many sorts of wolves there been.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Marry just as many sorts as there be knaves in the cards

sp.speaker: Shep. 2.
sp.p: Why that's four.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: First there are your court wolves, and those be
Foul eaters and clean drinkers.

sp.speaker: Shep. 2.
sp.p: And why clean drinkers?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why because when they be drunken they commonly cast up all, and so make cleansing week of't.

sp.speaker: Shep. 2.
sp.p: So sir, those are clean drinkers indeed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The next are your country wolves, nothing chokes them but plenty, they sing like Syrens when corn goes out by shipfulls, and dance after no tune but after an angel a bushel.

sp.speaker: She. 1.
sp.p: The halter take such corn-cutters.

sp.speaker: She. 2.
sp.p: Are there no city wolves?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A rope on them, yes, huge routs, you shall have long lane full of them; they'll feed upon any whore, carrion, thief, or any thing.

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.p: Have they such maws?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Maws? why man, fiddlers have no better stomachs,
I have known some of them eat up a lord at three bits.

sp.speaker: Shep. 2.
sp.p: Three bonds you mean.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: A knight is nobody with them,
A young gentleman is swallowed whole like a Gudgenon.

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.p: I wonder that gudgeon does not choke him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: A gudgeon choke him, if the throat of his conscience be sound, he'll gulp down any thing; five of your silken gallants are swallowed easier than a damask prune: for our city wolves do so roll my young prodigal first in wax, which is soft, till he look like a guilded pill, and then so finely wrap him up in satin which is sleek, that he goes down without chewing, and thereupon they are called slippery gallants.

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.p: I'll be no gentleman for that trick.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The last is your sea wolf, a horrible ravener to, he has a belly as big as a ship, and devours as much silk at a gulp as would serve forty dozen tailors against a Christmas day or a running at tilt.

sp.speaker: Shep. 1.
sp.p: Well, well, now our trap is set what shall we do with the wolves we catch?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why those that are great ones and more than our matches we'll let go, and the lesser wolves we will hang: shall it be so?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Ay, ay, each man to his stand. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Foul monster monger, who must live by that
Which is thy own destruction: why should men
Be natures bondslaves? Every creature else
Comes freely to the table of the earth;
That which for man alone doth all things bearen
Scarce gives him his true diet anywhere .
What spiteful winds breathe here? that not a tree
Spreads, forth a friendly arm? distressed Queen,
and most accursed babes; the earth that bears you
Like a proud mother, scorns to give you food: ha?
Thanks fate, I now defy thee starveling hunger,
Blessed tree, four lives grow in thy fruit, run taste it then,
Wise men serve first themselves than other men.
O me accursed and most miserable,
Help, help, some angel lay a listening ear
To draw my cry up; none to lend help? o
Then pine and die. Enter clown.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: A wolf caught, a wolf caught.

sp.speaker: Lap
sp.l: O help, I am no wolf good friend.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: No! what art thou then?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: A miserable wretch.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: An usurer?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: A broker then?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Mock not a man in woe, in a green wound,
Pour balsam and not physic.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Snails, he talks like a surgeon,
If you be one why do you not help yourself sir?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: I am no surgeon friend, my names Lapirus.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: How? A wolf caught hoa — lap what lap, hoa!

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Lapirus is my name dost thou not know me?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Yes, for a wolvish rascal that would have worried his own country.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Torture me not, I prithee, I am that wretch; a villain
I was once; but I am now —

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The devil in the vault; you sirrah, that betrayed your country, and the old King your uncle, there lie till one wolf devour another, thou treacherous rascal. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O me most miserable and wretched creature!
I now do find there's a revenging fate
That dooms bad men to be unfortunate.

div.head: Scene. 3.
div.stage: Enter Zenarchus, Tymethes, Amphridote, and Mazeres.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: We are observed.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Mazeres follows us.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O he's my protested servant, your sole rival.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: The devil he is.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: You'll make a hot suitor of him anon?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: He may be hot in th' end, his good parts sue for't,

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: He eyes us still.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: He does, you shall depart lady;
I'll take my leave on purpose in his presence,
He's jealous, and a kiss runs through his heart,
I'll make a thrust at him on your lip.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Death! minute favours? every step a kiss?
I think they count how the day goes by kissing,
'Tis passed four since I met them.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I have hit him in the call in stead of th' blood,
He sheds distractions, which are worse than wounds.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: But sirrah!

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Stays he to prove my rival? cursed be th' hour
Wherein I advised the King for his stay here,
I have set slaves to entrap him, yet none prosper,
I'll lay no more my faith upon their works
Th' are weak and loose, and like a rotten wall,
Leaning on them may hazard my own fall.
I'll use a swifter course, cut off long journeys,
And tedious ways that run my hopes passed breath,
I'll take the plain roaded way and hunt his death. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: So so, he departs with a knit brow, no matter;
When his frown begets earthquakes, haply then
'Twill shake me too: I shall stand firm till then.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Mass here 'a walks; I am far enough from myself,
I challenge all disguises except drinking
To hide me better; I give way to that,
For that indeed will thrust a white gentleman
Into a suit of mud, but whist I begin to be noted.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Ay, he changed upon't.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I marked him.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Good your honours, your most comfortable charitable relief
and devotion to a poor star crossed gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Pox on thee.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: I'm bare enough already if it like your honour.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: He did!

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Pox on thee? your young gallants love to give no alms ▪
But that that will stick by a man, that's one virtue in them:
He's not content to have my hat off, but he would have my hair off too.
Thank your good lordship.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: No! was that his action!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: It called him lord.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Nay he's a villain.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Good your honours! I have been a man in my time.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Why what art thou now?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.p: Kept goodly beasts, had 3. wives, 2. men uprising, 3. maids down lying; o good your kind honours.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Sfoot, I am a beggar myself.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Perhaps your lordship gets by it;
Good your sweet honour ▪

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: This fellow would be whipped.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Your lordship has forgotten since you were a beggar.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I'll give thee somewhat for that jest in troth.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: But now you are in private, shut your purse, and open your ear sir.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: He's dealing his devotion, hinder him not.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: I am not literally a beggar, as puritanical as I appear
The naked truth is you are happily desired.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Of the most
Sweet, delicate, divine, pleasing, ravishing creature

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Peace, peace, prithee peace.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: That ever made man's wishes perfect.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Nay, say not so; I saw one creature lately
Exceeds all humane form for true perfection; this may be beauteous.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: This for white and red sir, her honour and my oath sue for that pardon,
You must not know her name nor see her face.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: She rather chooseth death in her neglect
Than so to hazard life or lose respect.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: How shall I come at her?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Let your will
Subscribe to the sure means already wrought,
She shall be safely pleased, you safely brought.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Ha! and is this sheer faith, without any trick in't?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Let me perish in this office else; and I need wish
No more damnation than to die a pander.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Thou speakest well, when meet we?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Five is the fixed hour, upon to morrow's evening.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: So, the place?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Near to the further lodge.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Go to then, it holds honest all the way?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Else does there live no honesty but in lawyers.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Enough, five? and the furthest lodge? I'll meet thee.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Enjoy the sweetest treasure in a woman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Always excepting and the tyrant's gem.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What, have you done with the beggar?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: None that lives can say he has done with the beggar.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Hold conference so long with such a fellow?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p: How? are your wits perfect? if one should refuse to talk with every beggar, he might refuse brave company sometimes, gallants i'faith. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene. 4.
div.stage: Enter the old King, Fidelio, and Amorpho.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The loss of my dear Queen afflicts me more
Than all Lapirus cursed treacheries: inhuman monster!

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: [in the pit.]if you have humane forms to fit those voices
And hearts that may be pierced with miseries groans
Sent from a fainting spirit; pity a wretch,
A miserable man, prisoner to darkness,
Your charitable strengths this way repair,
And lift my flesh to the reviving air.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Alas, some travelling man, by night out stripped,
Missing his way into this danger slipped;
Set all our hands to help him; come, good man,
They that sit high may make their ends below.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Millions of thanks and praises.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You're heavy sir, who ere you be.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: There's weight within keeps down my soul and men

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: One full strength more makes our pains happy, poor strength helps the poor.

lg.l: So sir, you're welcome to — Lapirus? o. Lapi. falls down.
We do forgive thy treachery, revive,
'Tis pity and not hate makes goodness thrive.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: O that astonishment had left me dead!
Shame, sitting on my brow, weighs down my head:
Even thus the guilt of my abhorred sin,
Flashed in my face when I beheld the Queen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our Queen! o where, Lapirus? tell the rest.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Within this forest with her babes distressed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Which way? lead dear Lapirus.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Follow me then.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not only shall we quit thy soul's offence
But give thy happy labour recompense. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter the old Queen weeping, with both her infants, the one dead; she lays down the other on a bank, and goes to bury the dead, expressing much grief. Enter the former shepherds, walking by carelessly, at last they espy the child and strive for it, at last the clown gets it, and dandles it, expressing all signs of joy to them. Enter again the Queen, she looks for her babe and finding it gone, wrings her hands; the shepherds see her, then whisper together, then beckon to her; she joyfully runs to them, they return her child, she points to her breasts, as meaning she should nurse it, they all give her money, the clown kisses the babe and her, and so exeunt several ways. Then enter Lapirus, the old King, Amorpho, and Fidelio, they miss the Queen and so expressing great sorrow. Exeunt.
div.l: The miserable Queen expecting still
The infant's succour from Lapirus' hand
Who wants himself; it chanced through extreme want
The youngest died, and this so near his end
That had not shepherds happily passed by
And on the babe cast a compassionate eye,
And snatched the child out of the arms of death
Where the sad mother left it, the same hour
Had been his grave that gives his life new power.
Thus the distressed Queen to them unknown
Was as a nurse received unto her own.
Whose sight Lapirus missing ▪ having led
The King her husband to this hapless place,
They all depart in extreme height of grief
To get unto their own sad wants relief. Exit.

div.head: Scene. 1.
div.stage: Enter Roxano with his disguise in his hand.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.p: This is the farther lodge, the place of meeting; the hour scarce come yet — well — I was not born to this, there's not a hair to choose betwixt me and a pander in this case, shift it off as well as I can: I do envy this fellow's happiness now; and could cut his throat at pleasure: I could e'en gnaw feathers now to think of his downy felicity. I that could never aspire above a dairy wench, the very cream of my fortunes; that he should bathe in nectar, and I most unfortunate in buttermilk, this is good dealing now, is't?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I'll have some other, for he must not live.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Who's this? my lord Mazeres discontent ▪
He has been to seek me twice, and privately,
I wonder at the business; I'm no statesman;
If I be, 'tis more than I know; I protest therefore
I dare not call it in question; what should he make with me?
sp.p: I'll discover myself to him — if th' other come in the mean time so I may be caught bravely, yet 'tis scarce the hour, I'll put it to the trial.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Roxano in my judgement had been fittest,
And farthest from suspect of such a deed
Because he keeps in the castle.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: My loved lord.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Roxano!

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: The same my lord.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I was to seek thee twice;
Tell me Roxano, have I any power in thee? do I move there,
Or any part of me flow in thy blood?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: As far as life my lord.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: As far as love man, I ask no further.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Touch me then my lord, and try my mettle.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: First there's gold for thee,
After which follow favour, eminence,
And all those gifts which fortune calls her own.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Well my lord.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: There's one tymethes son to the banished King,
Lives about court, Zenarchus gives him grace,
That fellow's my disease, I thrive not with him,
He's like a prison chain shook in my ears
I take no sleep for him, his favours mad me.
My honours and my dignities are dreams
When I behold him; that right arm can ease me,
I will not boast my bounties, but for ever
Live rich and happy: thou art wise farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Hum, what news is here now? thou art wise farewell.
By my troth I think it is a part of wisdom to take gold
When it is offered, many wise men will do't: that I learned
Of my learned council: this is worth thinking on now.
sp.p:
To kill Tymethes, so strangely beloved by a lady, and so monstrously detested by a lord? here's gold to bring Tymethes, and here's gold to kill Tymethes. Ay, let me see, which weighs heaviest; by my faith I think the killing gold will carry't: I shall like many a bad lawyer, run my conscience upon the greatest fee; who gives most is like to fare best. I like my
safety so much the worse in this business in that lord Mazeres is his professed enemy: he's the King's bosom, he blows his thoughts into him; and I had rather be torn with whirlwinds than fall into any of their furies. Troth as far as I can see, the wisest course is to play the knave, lay open this venery, betray him; but see my lord again.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Hast thou thought of me? may I do good upon thee?
I'll out of recreation, make thee worthy; play honours to thy hand.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Art thou resolved? and I will be thy lord.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: It will appear I am so; be proud of your revenge before I name it;
Never was man so fortunate in his hate,
I'll give you a whole age but to think how.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Thou mak'st me thirst.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Tymethes meets me here.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Here? excellent, on Roxano; he meets thee here.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: I meant at first to betray all to you sir: understand that my lord.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I'faith I do.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Then thus my lord — he comes.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Withdraw behind the lodge, relate it briefly.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: A delicate sweet creature? slight, who should it been?
I must not know her name, nor see her face?
It may be some trick to have my bones bastinadoed
Well, and so sent back again; what say you to a blanquetting
Faith, so 'twere done by a lady and her chambermaids
I care not, for if they toss me in the blankets
I'll toss them in the sheets, and that's one for th' other.
A man may be led into a thousand villainies; but the fellow swore enough,
And here's blood apt enough to believe him.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I both admire the deed, and my revenge.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: My lord I'll make your way.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Thou mak'st thy friend. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Art come? we meet e'en jump upon a minute.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: I but you'll play the better jumper of the two.
I shall not jump so near as you by a handful.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: How! at a running leap?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: That is more hard;
At a running leap you may give me a handful.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: So, so, what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Nothing but put this hood over your head.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: How? I never went blindfold before.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: You never went otherwise sir; for all folly is blind;
Besides sir, when we see the sin we act,
We think each trivial crime a bloody fact.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Well followed of a serving man.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Serving-men always follow their master's sir,

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: No not in their mistresses.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: There I leave you sir.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I desire to be left when I come there sir.
But faith sincerely is there no trick in this?
Prithee deal honestly with me.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Honestly, if protestation be not honest,
I know not what to call it.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Why, if she affect me so truly, she might trust me with her knowledge,
I could be secret to her chief actions, why I love women too well.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: She'll trust you the worse for that sir.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Why because I love women?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: O sir, 'tis most common,
He that loves women, is ne'er true to woman.
Experience daily proves he loveth none
With a true heart, that affects more than one.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Your wit runs nimbly sir, pray use your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Why then good-night sir. He puts on the hood.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Mass the candles out.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: O sir the better sports taste best in th' night,
And what we do in the dark we hate i'th' light.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: A good doer mayst thou prove, for thy experience;
Come give me thy hand, thou mayst prove an honest lad,
But however I'll trust thee.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: O sir, first try me,
But we protract good hours, come follow me sir,
Why this is right your sportive gallants prize,
Before they'll lose their sport they'll lose their eyes. Exeu.

div.head: Scen. 2.
div.stage: Enter the Queen and four servants, she with a book in her hand.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O my fear-fighting blood! aren you all here.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: All at your pleasure madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: That's my wish, and my opinion
Hath ever been persuaded of your truths,
And I have found you willing t'all employments
We put into your charge.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: In our faith's madam.

sp.speaker: Servant 3.
sp.l: For we are bound in duty to your bounty.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Will you to what I shall prescribe swear secrecy?

sp.speaker: Servant 4.
sp.l: Try us, sweet lady, and you shall prove our faiths ▪

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: To all things that you hear or see
I swear you all to secrecy;
I pour my life into your breasts,
There my doom or safety rests.
If you prove untrue to all
Now I rather choose to fall
With loss of my desire, than light
Into the tyrant's wrathful spite:
But in vain I doubt your trust,
I never found your hearts but just.
On this book your vows arrive,
And as in truth in favour thrive.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We wish no higher, so we swear.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Like jewels all your vows I'll wear.
Here, take this paper, there those secrets dwell,
Go read your charge, which I should blush to tell.
All's sure, I nothing doubt of safety now,
to which each servant hath combined his vow.
Roxano, that begins it trustily,
I cannot choose but praise him, he's so needful,
There's nothing can be done about a lady
But he is for it; honest Roxano;
Even from our head to feet he's so officious,
The time draws on, I feel the minutes here,
No clock so true as love that strikes in fear. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene. 3.
div.stage: Soft music, a table with lights set out. Arras spread.
Enter Roxano leading Tymethes. Mazeres meets them.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: How far lack I yet of my blind pilgrimage?

sp.speaker: Maz
sp.l: Whist, Roxano ▪

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: You are at your — in my lord, away, I'll help
You to a disguise.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Enough. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Methinks I walk in a vault all under ground.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: And now your long lost eyes again are found: good morrow sir. Pulls off the hood.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: By the mass the day breaks.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Rest here my lord and you shall find content,
Catch your desires, stay here, they shall be sent.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Though it be night, 'tis morning to that night which brought me hither,
Ha! the ground spread with arras? what place is this?
Rich hangings? fair room gloriously furnished?
Lights and their luster? riches and their splendour?
'Tis no mean creatures, these dumb tokens witness;
Troth I begin to affect my hostess better;
I love her in her absence, though unknown,
For courtly form that's here observed and shown.

div.stage: Loud music. Enter 2. with a banquet; other 2. with lights; they set 'em down and depart, making obeisance. Roxano takes one of them aside.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Valesta? yes, the same; 'tis my lady's pleasure,
You give to me your coat, and vizarded attend without
Till she employ you — so now, this disguise
Serves for my lord Mazeres, for he watches
But fit occasion: lecher, now beware,
Securely sit and fearless quaff and eat,
You'll find sour sauce still after your sweet meat. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: The servants all in vizards? by this light
I do admire the carriage of her love;
For I account that woman above wise
Can sin and hide the shame from a man's eyes.
They never do their easy sex more wrong,
Than when they venture fame upon man's tongue.
Yet I could swear concealment in love's plot,
But happy woman that believes me not.
Whate'er is spoke or to be spoke seems fit,
All still concludes her happiness and wit.

div.stage: Loud music, enter Roxano, Mazeres and the 4. Servants, with dishes of sweet meats, Roxano places them: each having delivered his dish makes low obeisance to Tymethes.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: This banquet from her own hand received grace
Herself prepared it for you; as appears
By the choice sweets it yields, able to move
A man passed sense, to the delights of love,
I bid you welcome as her most prised guest,
First to this banquet, next to pleasure's feast.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Who ere she be we thank her, and commend
Her care and love to entertain a friend.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: That speaks her sex's rareness, for to woman,
The darkest path love treads is clear and common;
She wishes your content may be as great
As if her presence filled that other seat.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Convey my thanks to her, and fill some wine.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: My lord Mazeres caught the office
I can't but laugh to see how well he plays
The devil in a vizard; damns where he crouches; little thinks the prince
under that face lurks his lives enemy,
Yet he but keeps the fashion; great men kill
As flatterers stab, who laugh when they mean ill.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Now could I poison him fitly, aptly, rarely,
My vengeance speaks me happy; there it goes.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Some wine?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: It comes my lord.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My lady begun to you sir, and doth commend,
This to your heart, and with it her affection.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I'll pledge her thankfully; there remove that.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: And in this my revenge must be removed
Where first I left it, now my abused wrath
Pursues thy ruin in this dangerous path.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: That cup hath quite dashed my lord Mazeres.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Return my faith, my reverence, my respect,
And tell her this, which courteously I find,
She hides her face, but lets me see her mind.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: I would not taste of such a banquet to feel that which follows it,
For the love of an empress. 'tis more dangerous to be a lecher
Than to enter upon a breach; yet how securely he munches
His thoughts are sweeter than the very meats before him:
He little dreams of his destruction;
His horrible fearful ruin which cannot be withstood,
The end of venery is disease or blood

div.stage: Soft music. Enter the Queen masked in her nightgown; her maid with a shirt and a night cap.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I have not known one happier for his pleasure
Than in that state we are; 'tis a strange trick,
And sweetly carried; by this light a delicate creature,
And should have a good face if all hit right;
For they that have good bodies and bad faces
Were all mismatched, and made up in blind places.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: The wind and tide serve sir, you have lighted upon
a sea of pleasure; here's your sail sir, and your top streamer
A fair wrought shirt and a nightcap.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I shall make a sweet voyage of this.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Ay, if you knew all sir.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Is not all known yet? what's to be told?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Five hundred crowns in the shirt sleeve in gold.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: 'Tis my good lady's pleasure,
No clouds eclipse her bounty, she shines clear,
Some like that pleasure best that costs most dear;
Yet I think your lordship is not of that mind now;
You like that best that brings a banquet with it, and 500. Crowns.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I by this light do I; and I think thou art of my mind.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: We jump somewhat near sir.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: But what does she mean to reward me afore hand?
I may prove an eunuch now for ought she knows.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: O sir, I ne'er knew any of your hair but he was absolute at the game.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Faith we are much of a colour; but here's a note, what says it?
He reads.our love and bounty shall increase
So long as you regard our peace.
Unless your life you would forgo,
Who we are seek not to know.
Enjoy me freely: for your sake
This dangerous shift I undertake.
Be therefore wise, keep safe your breath,
You cannot see me under death.
I'd be loath to venture so far for the sight of any creature under heaven.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Nay sir I think you may see a thousand faces better cheap.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Well, I will shift me instantly, and be content
With my groaping fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: O sir, you'll grope to purpose. Exit.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I'll after thee, and see the measure of my vengeance upheaped
His ruin is my charge; I have seen that
This night would make one blush through this vizard.
Like lightning in a tempest her lust shows,
Or drinking drunk in thunder, horrible:
For on this act a thousand dangers wait,
The King will seize him in his burning fury
And seal his vengeance on his reeking breast,
Though I make panders use of ear and eye
No office vile to dam mine enemy.
This course is but the first, 'twill not rest there,
The next shall change him into fire and air. Exit.

div.head: Scene. 1.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Nay, did ere subtlety match it?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: 'Slight, led to a lady hoodwinked!
Placed in state, and banqueted in vizards.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: All by this light: but all this nothing was
To the delicious pleasures of her bed.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Who should this be?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Nay inquire not brother,
I'd give one eye to see her with the other.
Seest thou this jewel? in the midst of night
I slipped it from her veil, unfelt of her,
'T may be so kind unto me as to bring
Her beauty to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Canst not guess at her, nor at the place?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: At neither for my heart; why I'll tell thee man
'Twas handled with such art, such admired cunning,
What with my blindness and their general darkness,
That when mine eyes received their liberty, I was ne'er the nearer.
To them in full form I appeared shrouded
But all their lights to me were masked and clouded.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Fore heaven I do admire the cunning of't.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Nay you cannot out vie my admiration,
I had a feeling of't beyond your passion.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Well, blow this over, see, our sister comes.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Art sure Mazeres that he courts our daughter?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I'm sure of more my lord, she favours him.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: That beggar?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Worse my lord, that villain traitor, and yet worse my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Pardon my lord, a riper time shall bring him forth.
Behold him there my lord. Tymethes kisses her.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Dares she so far forget respect to us,
And dim her own lustre to give him grace?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Favours are grown to custom twixt them both,
Letters, close banquets, whisperings, private meetings.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: I'll make them dangerous meetings.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: In faith my lord I'll have this jewel.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: 'Tis not my gift lady.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: What's that Mazeres?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Marry, my lord, she courtly begs a jewel of him
Which he keeps back as courtly, with fair words.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I have sworn my lord.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Why upon that condition
You'll keep it safe and close from all strange eyes
Not wronging me, 'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I swear.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: It shall suffice.

div.stage: They kiss, and exit Zenarchus and Amphridote.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: 'Tis hers my lord, at which they part in kisses.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: I'll make those meetings bitter; both shall rue,
We have found Mazeres to this minute true.

lg.l: No trick to see this lady? heart of ill fortune!
The jewel that was begged from me too was
The hope I had to gain her wished for knowledge.
Well; here's a heart within will not be quiet;
The eye is the sweet feeder of the soul,
When then taste wants, that keeps the memory whole;
'Tis bad to be in darkness all know well,
than not to see her what doth it want of hell?
Unless your life you would forgo,
Whom we are, seek not to know.
As if she'd suffer death to threaten me
Whom she so bounteously and firmly loves?
No trick? excellent, 'twill fit; make use of that.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Enough, thou'rt honest; I affect thee much;
Go, train him to his ruin. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Let me alone my lord; doubt not I'll train him:
Perhaps sir I have the art.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: O, I know thy mind.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: The further lodge?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Enough, I'll meet thee presently.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Why so; I like one that will make an end of himself at few words;
A man that hath a quick perseverance in ill:
A leaping spirit; he'll run through horrors jaws
To catch a sin; but to o'ertake a virtue
He softly paces, like a man that's sent
Some tedious dark, unprofitable journey.
Corrupt is nature, she loves nothing more
Than what she most should hate, there's nothing springs
Apace in man but grey hairs, cares, and sins.Exit

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I'll see her come what can; but what can prove?
She cannot seek my death, that seeks my love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: My lord, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I know not what;
The King sent.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Well, we obey.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Here comes his highness. Enter tyrant.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: How now what's she?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I my lord?
Your highness knew me once, your most obedient daughter.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: They lie that tell me so, this is not she.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: No, my lord?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: No, for as thou art I know thee not,
And I shall strive still to forget thee more;
Thou neither bearest in memory my respects
Nor thy own worths; how can we think of thee
But as of a dejected worthless creature?
So far beneath our grace and thy own luster, that we disdain to know thee.
Was there no choice 'mong our selected nobles
To make thy favourite besides Tymethes?
Son to our enemy, a wretch, a beggar?
Dead to all fortunes, honours, or their hopes,
Besides his breath, worth nothing; abject wretch,
To place thy affection so vigorously
On him can ne'er requite it; deny't not,
We know the favours thou hast given him,
Pledges of love, close letters, private meetings,
And whisperings are customary twixt you.
Come, which be his gifts? whereabout lie his pledges?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Your grace hath been injuriously informed,
I ne'er received pledge.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Impudent creature,
When in our sight and hearing shamefully undervaluing thy best honours
and setting by all modesty of blood thou bēg'dst a jewel of him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O pardon men my lord, I had forgotten, here 'tis,
That is the same, and all that ere was his.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Ha! this! how came this hither?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I gave it you my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Who gave it thee?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Tymethes.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: He! who gave it him?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I know not that my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Then here it sticks, Mazeres!

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: My lord!

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: 'Tis my Queens, my Queens, Mazeres.
How to him came this?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I can resolve your highness.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Can Mazeres?

sp.speaker: Maz
sp.l: He is some ape, the husk falls from him now,
And you shall know his inside: he's a villain,
A traitor to the pleasures of your bed.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O, I shall burst with torment.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: He's received this night
Into her bosom.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: I feel a whirl wind in me
Ready to tear the frame of my mortality.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I traced him to the deed.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: And saw it done?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I abused my eyes in the true survey of't,
Tainted my hearing with lascivious sounds;
My loyalty did prompt me to be sure
Of what I found so wicked and impure.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: 'Tis spring tide in my gall, all my blood's bitter,
Puh, lungs too.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: This night.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Lodovico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.l: How cam'st thou up? let's hear.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: My lord, my first beginning was a broker.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: A knave from the beginning; there's no hopē of him, Sertorio? Enter Sertorio.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: We know thee just, how cam'st thou up? let's hear.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: From no desert that I can challenge but your highness' favour.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Thou art honest in that answer; go, report we are 40. leagues off
Rid forth: spread it about the castle cunningly.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I'll do it faithfully my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Do't cunningly,
Go, if thou shouldst do't faithfully thou liest;
I'm lost by violence through all my senses,
I'm blind with rage, Mazeres, guide me forth
I tread in air, and see no foot nor path,
I have lost myself, yet cannot lose my wrath.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: What have I heard? it dares not be but true ▪
Tymethes taken in adulterate trains,
And with the Queen my mother? now I hate him,
As beauty abhors years, or usurer's charity;
He does appear unto my eye a leper
Full of sins black infection, foul adultery:
Cursed be the hour in which I first did grace him,
And let Mazeres starve in my disdain
That hath so long observed me with true love,
Whose loyalty in this approves the same.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: My love? my lord I should say, but would say my love.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I do beseech your grace for what I have done
Lay no oppressing censure upon me;
I could not but in honesty reveal it,
Not envying in that he was my rival,
Nor in the force of any ancient grudge
But as the deed in its own nature craved,
So 'mong the rest it was revealed to me:
appēaring so detested that yourself
Gracious and kind, had you but seen the manner
Would have thrown by all pity and remorse
And took my office or one more in force.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Rise dear Mazeres, in our favours rise,
So far am I from censure to reprove thee
That in my hate to him I choose and love thee.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: If constant service may be called desert, I shall deserve.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Man hath no better part.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Why this was happily observed and followed; aside .
The King will to the castle late tonight ,
And tread through all the vaults, I must attend.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I wish that at first sight th' hadst forced his end. Exit.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: 'Tis better thus; so my revenge imports;
Now thrive my plots, the end shall make me great,
She mine, the crown sits here I am then completed. Exit.

div.head: Scene. 3.
div.stage: Enter Queen and her maid with a light.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: So, leave us here a while, bear back the light,
I would not be discovered if he come,
You know his entertainment, so be gone,
I am not cheerful troth, what point soe'er
My powers arrive at: I desire a league
With desolate darkness, and disconsolate fancies,
There is no music in my soul tonight .
What should I fear when all my servants faiths
Sleep in my bounty, and no bribes not threats,
Can wake them from my safety? for the King,
He's forty leagues road forth, I heard it lately:
Yet heaviness like a tyrant, proud in night
Usurps my power, rules where it hath no right. She sleeps.

div.stage: Enter Roxano as she sleeps with Tymethes hoodwinked.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Methinks this a longer voyage than the first?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Pleasures once tasted makes the next seem worse.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Is that the trick?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: O sir, experience proves it,
You came at first to enjoy what you ne'er knew,
Now all is but the same whate'er you do.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I'll prove that false, the sight of her is new.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: I have forgotten a business to my lord Mazeres,
My safety to the King relies upon't,
You are in the house my lord, this is the withdrawing room.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I see nothing.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: No matter sir, as long as you have
Feeling enough.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Is the hood off?

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: 'Tis here in my hand sir,
I must crave pardon, leave you here a while,
But as you love my safety and your own
Remove not from this room till my return.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Well here's my hand I will not.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: 'Tis enough sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Hist, art gone? then boldly I step forth
Cunning discoverer of an unknown beauty
As subtle as her plot: thou art masked too,
Show me a little comfort, in this condensive darkness;
Play the flatterer laugh in my face;
Why here's enough to perfect all my wishes;
With this I taste of that forbidden fruit
Which as she says death follows; death 'twill sting,
Soft, what rooms this? let's see, 'tis not the former
I was entertained in, no, it some what differs:
Rich hangings still, court deckings, ay, and all —
O all that can be in man's wish comprised
Is in thy love immortal, in thy graces.
I am not the same flesh, my touch is altered.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Hast thou betrayed me? what hast thou attempted?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Nothing that can be prejudicial
To the sweet peace of those illustrious graces.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O my most certain ruin?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Admired lady hear me, hear my vow,

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O miserable youth none saves thee now.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: By that which man holds dearest dreadful Queen.
And all that can be in a vow contained
I'll prove as true, secret, and vigilant
As ever man observed with serious virtue
The dreadful call of his departing soul.
Your own soul to your secrets, shall not prove more true
Than mine to it, to them, to all, to you.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O misery of affection built on breath?
Were I as far passed my belief in heaven
As in man's oaths, I were the foulest devil.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: May I eat and ne'er be nourished, live and know nothing,
Love without enjoying, if ever —

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Come, this is more than needs.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: There's comfort then.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You that profess such truth, shall I enjoin you
To one poor penance then to try your faith?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: Be't what it will command it.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Spend but this hour, wherein you have offended
In true repentance of your sin, and all
Your hasty youth stands guilty of, and being clear,
You shall enjoy that which you hold most dear.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: And if this penance I perform not truly
May I henceforth ne'er be received to favour.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Why then I'll leave you to your task a while:
Most wretched, doubtful, strange distracted woman,
E'en drawn in pieces betwixt love and fear,
I weep in thought of both: bold venturous youth,
Twice I writ death, yet would he seek to know me,
He'll make no conscience where his oaths bestow me ▪Exit.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.l: I'm glad all's so well passed, and she appeased,
I swear I did expect a harder penance
When she began to enjoin me; why, this is wholesome
For soul and body, though I seldom use it.
Her wisdom is as pleasing as her beauty,
I never knew affection hastier born,
With more true art and less suspicion:
It so amazed me to know her my mistress
I had no power to close the light again,
sp.stage: Enter the Queen with two pistols.
sp.l: Unhappy that I was, peace, here she comes.
Down to thy penance, think of thy whole youth,
From the first minute that the womb conceived me
To this full heaped hour I do repent me,
With heart as penitent as a man, dissolving,
Of all my sins, born with me, and born of me;
Dishonest thoughts and sights, the paths of youth,
So thrive in mercy as I end in truth.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Fly to thy wish, I pray it may be given,
Man in a twinkling is in earth and heaven:
I dealt not like a coward with thy soul,
Nor took it unprepared.
I gave him time to put his armour on
And sent him forth like a celestial champion,
I loved thee with more care and truer moan,
Since thou must die to taste more deaths than one
Too much by this pity and love confesses,
Had any warning fastened on thy senses:
Rash, unadvised youth, whom my soul weeps for,
How oft I told thee this attempt was death?
Yet wouldst thou venture on, fond man and knenw?
But what destruction will not youth pursue?
Here long mightst thou have lived, been loved, enjoyed,
Had not thy will thy happiness destroyed;
Thoughtest thou by oaths to have thy deedēs well born?
Thou shouldst have come when man was ne'er forsworn ▪
They are dangerous now; witness this breach of thine;
Who's false to his own faith, will ne'er keep mine.
We must be safe, young man, the deed's unknown,
There are more loves, honours no more than one.
Yet spite of death I'll kiss thee; o strange ill,
that for our fears we should our comforts kill?
Whom shall I trust with this poor bleeding body?
Yonder's a secret vault runs through the castle
There for a while convey him; hapless boy
That never knew how dear 'twas to enjoy.
O 'Me confounded everlastingly,
Damned to a thousand tortures in that sight
What shall I frame? my lordShe runs to him.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: What's she?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O my sweet dearest lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Thy name?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thy poor affrighted and indangered Queen.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O, I know thee now.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Did not your majesty hear the piteous shrieks
Of an enforced lady?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Yes, whose were they?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Mine my most worthy lord; behold this villain
Sealed with his just desert: light here my King,
This violent youth, whom till this night, I saw not,
Being, as it seems, acquainted with the footsteps
Of that dark passage, broke through the vault upon me
And with a secret lantern searched me out;
And seized me at my orisons alone
And bringing me by violence to this room
Far from my guard, or any hope of rescue,
Intending here the ruin of my honour;
But in the strife, as the good gods ordained it
Reaching for succour, I lighted on a pistol,
Which I presumed was not without his charge,
Than I redeemed mine honour from his lust,
So he that sought my fall lies in the dust.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O let me embrace thee for a brave unmatchable
Precious, unvalued admirable whore.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Ha! what says my lord?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Come hither, yet draw nearer, how came this man
To's end? I would hear that, I would learn cunning,
Tell me that I may wonder and so lose thee.
There is no art like this; let me partake
A subtlety no devil can imitate,
Speak, why is all so contrary to time?
He down and you up? ha, why thus?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I am sorry for my lord, I understand him not.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: The deed is not so monstrous in itself
As is the art which ponders home the deed;
The cunning doth amaze me passed the sin,
That he should fall before my rage begin.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Come hither yet, one of those left hands give me,
Thou hast no right at all;
Nothing but put a ring upon a finger

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: That's a wrong finger for a ring my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: And what was he on whom you bounteously bestowed this jewel?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I do not like that word. aside

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Look well upon't, dost know it? Ay, and start.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O heaven, how came this hither?
Your highness gave me this, this is mine own.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: 'Tis the same ring, but yet not the same stone
Mystical strumpet, dost thou yet presume
Upon thy subtle strength? shak'st thou not yet?
