Or is it only art makes women constant, whom nature makes so loose?
I looked for gracious lightning from thy cheeks,
I see none yet; for a relenting eye,
I can see no such sight; lust keeps in all;
My witness? where's my witness? rise in the same form.

div.stage: Enter from below, Mazeres habited like Roxano.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O I'm betrayed.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Is not you woman an adulteress.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Yes, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Was not this fellow catched for her desire?
Brought in a mist? banqueted and received
To all her amplest pleasures!

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: True, my lord,
I brought him, saw him feasted and received,

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Down, down, we have too much.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O 'tis Roxano.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: So, by this sleight I have deceived them both,
I'm taken for him I strive to make her loath. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Needs here more witnesses? I'll call up more.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O no, here lies a witness 'gainst myself
Sooner believed than all their hired faiths;
Doom me unto my death, only except
The lingering execution of your look;
Let me not live tormented in that brow,
I do confess.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O I felt no quick till now.
All witnesses to this were but dead flesh
I was insensible of all but this.
Would I had given my kingdom so conditioned
That thou hadst ne'er confessed it.
Now I stand by the deed, see all in action,
The close conveyance, cunning passages,
The artful fetch, the whisperlng close disguising;
The hour, the banquet, and the bawdy tapers ▪
All stick in mine eye together; yet thou shalt live.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Torment me not with life, it asks but death.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O hadst thou not confessed? hadst thou no sleight?
Where was thy cunning there?
I see it now in thy confession.
Thou shalt not die as long as this is meat,
Thou killed'st a buck which thou thyself shalt eat.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Dear sir?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Here's deer struck dead with thy own hand,
'Tis venison for thy own tooth, thou knowest the relish
A dearer place hath been thy taster; hoa, Sertorio! Lodovico

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Drag hence that body, see it quartered straight,
No living wrath can I extend upon't,
Else torments, horrors, gibbets, racks and wheels
Had with a thousand deaths presented him,
Ere he had tasted one; yet thou shalt live.
Here, take this taper lighted, kneel, and weep,
I'll try which is spent first, that of thine eye,
I'll provide food for thee, thou shalt not die.
If there be hell for sins that men commit,
Marry a strumpet and she keeps the pit. Exit.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I feared this misery long before it came,
My ominous dreams, and fearful dreadfulness
Promised this issue long before 'twas born.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Yonder she kneels, little suspecting me
The neat discoverer of her venery.
I were full safe had I Roxano's life
Which in this stream I fish for; how now lady;
So near the earth suits not a living Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Under the earth were safer and far happier.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: What is't that can drive you to such discomforts ▪
To prize your glories at so mean a rate?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: The treachery of my servants, good my lord;

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Dare they prove treacherous? most ignoble vassals,
To the sweet peace of so divine a mistress?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I'm sure one villain, whom I dear loved,
Of whom my trust had made election chief,
Perfidiously betrayed me to the fury
Of my tempestuous unappeased lord.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Let me but know him, that I may bestow
My service to your grace upon his heart
And thence deserve a mistress like yourself.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: O me, too soon behold him.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Madam, stand by, let him not see the light.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Now I expect reward.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: He dies were he my kinsman for that guilt,
Though 'twere as far to's heart as 'tis to th' hilt.

sp.speaker: Rox.
sp.l: Ha? what was that? there's a reward with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Fall villain, for betraying of thy lady,
Such things must never creep about the earth
to poison them right use of service — a trencher!

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: This is some poor revenge, thanks good my lord,
Into that cave with him from whence he rose
Not long since and betrayed me to the King.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: O villain, in, and overtake thy soul.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Here's a perplexed breast, let that warm steel
Perform but the like service upon me,
And live the rarest friend to a Queen's wish.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: O pardon me, that were too full of evil,
I threat not angels though I smite the devil:
Doubt not your peace, the King will be appeased
There I'll bestow my service.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: We are pleased.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: As much as comes to nothing; I'll not sue
To urge the King from that he urged him to. Exit.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Betrayed where I reposed most trust? o heaven,
There is no misery, fit match for mine.

div.stage: Enter tyrant Sertorio, Lodovico, bringing in Tymethes' limbs.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: So, bring 'em forward yet, there, there bestow them,
Before her eyes lay the divided limbs
Of her desired paramour; so, you're welcome,
Lady you see your cheer, fine flesh, course fare,
Sweet was your lust, what can be bitter there?
By heaven, no other food thy taste shall have ▪
Till in thy bowels those corpses find a grave.
Which to be sure of, come, I'll lock thee safe
From the world's pity: hang those quarters up,
The bottom drinks the worst in pleasure's cup. Exeunt omn.

div.head: Scene. 1.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: O my Tymethes! truest joy on earth!
Hath thy fate proved so flinty? so perverse?
To the sweet spring both of thy youth and hopes?
This was Mazeres spite, that cursed rival,
And if I fail not, his own plot shall shower
Upon his bosom like a falling tower.
My worthy lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O, you should have seen us sooner.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Why my lord!

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: The quarters of your friend passed by in triumph,
A sight that 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 had pleased you well.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 villain to my father's pleasure,
No friend of mine ▪ the sight had pleased me 〈◊〉
Had I not like Mazeres, run my hate
Into the sin before it grew to act;
And killed it ere't had knotted ▪ 'twas rare service,
If your vexed majesty conceive it right.
In politic Mazeres, serving more
In this discovery, his own vicious malice
Than any true peace that should make you perfect:
Suffering the hateful treason to be done
He might have stopped in his confusion.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Most certain.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Good your majesty bethink you
In manly temper and considerate blood;
Went he the way of loyalty, or your quiet,
After he saw the courtesies exceed
T'abuse your peace, and trust them with the deed?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O no, none but a traitor would have done it.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: For my lord, weight indifferently.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: I do, I do.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What makes it heinous, burdensome, and monstrous,
fills you with such distractions, breeds such furies
In your incensed breast, but the deed doing?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Th'intent had been sufficient for his death,
And that full satisfaction; but the act —

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Insufferable,
Sertorio! where's Sertorio. Enter Sertorio.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Seek out Mazeres suddenly, peace Zenarchus
Let me alone to trap him.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: It may prove,
Behold my friend, how I express my love.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O villain, had he pierced him at first sight,
Where I have one grief, I had missed ten thousand by't.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I dreamt of some new honours for my late service,
And I wondered how he could keep off so long from my desert,

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Mazeres?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: My loved lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: I am forgetful
I am in thy debt some dignities Mazeres,
What shift shall we make for thee? thy late service
Is warm still in our memory and dear favour:
Prithee discover to's the manner how
Thou tookest them subtly.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I was received into a waiter's room my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Thou wast!

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: And in a vizard helped to serve the banquet.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: Saw him conveyed into a chamber privately.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: And still thou lettest him run?

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I let him play my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: I watched still near, till her arms clasped him.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: And there thou lettest him rest.

sp.speaker: Maz.
sp.l: There he was caught my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: So art thou here; drag him to execution he shall die.
With tortures 'bove the thought of tyranny. Exit.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: No words are able to express my gladness,
'Tis such a high borne rapture that the soul
Partakes it only.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: My lord Mazeres led
Unto his death?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It proves too true dear Princess.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Cursed be the mouth that doomed him, and for e'er
Blasted the hand that parts him from his life.
Was there none fit to practise tyranny on
But whom our heart elected? misery of love!
I must not live to think oft.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Here's my sister,
I could not bring that news will please her better,
My news brings that command over your passions, you must be merry.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Have you warrant for't brother?

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Yes, strong enough i'faith; hear me, Mazeres
By this time is at his everlasting home;
Where ere his body lies, I struck the stroke
I wrought a bitter pill that quickly choked him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O me, my soul will out, some wine there hoa!

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Wine for our sister, for the news is worth it.

div.stage: Enter Lod ▪ with wine and exit.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: It will prove dear to both; so, give it me; now leave us.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Revenge ne'er brought forth a more happy issue
Than I think mine to be.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I'm setting forth Mazeres, here Zenarchus.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Thou art not like this hour, jovial.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I shall be after this.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: That does't if any,
Wine doth both help defects, and causeth many.
Here's to the deed faith of our last revenge.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Dying men prophesy, faith 'tis our last end;
Now I must tell you brother, that I hate you,
In that you hive betrayed my loved Mazeres.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: His deed was loyal, his discovery just,
he brought to light a monster and his lust.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Nay if you grow so strumpet like in your behaviour to me,
I'll quickly cool that insolence.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Peace, peace,
There is a champion fights for me unseen,
I need not fear thy threats.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Indeed no harlot
But has her champion, besides bawd and varlet; o!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Why la you now such gear will ne'er thrive with you.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: I'm sick of thy society, poison to mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: 'Tis lower in thy breast the poison lies.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: 'Tis for Mazeres.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: O you virtuous powers,
What a right strumpet? poison under love?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: That man can ne'er be safe that divides love. She dies.

sp.speaker: Zen.
sp.l: Nor she be honest can so soon impart,
O ware that woman that can shift her heart. Dyes.

div.head: Scene. 2.
div.stage: Thunder and lightning. A blazing star appears.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Ha? thunder? and thou marrow melting blast
Quick winged lightning; and thou blazing star,
I like not thy prodigious bearded fire;
Thy beams are fatal: ha? behold the influence
Of all their malice in my children's mines?
Their states malignant powers have envied,
And for some haste struck with their envies died:
'Tis ominous; within there?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Here my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Convey those bodies a while from my fight.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Both dead my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Yes, and we safe, our death we needed less fear,
Usurper's issue oft proves dangerous,
We depose others, and they poison us,
I have found it on records, 'tis better thus.

div.stage: Enter the old King, Lapirus, Fidelio, Amorpho, all disguised like pilgrims.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: My lord, this castle is but slightly guarded.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis as I hoped and wished; now bless us heaven,
What horrid and inhuman spectacle
Is yonder that presents itself to sight?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: It seems three quarters of a man hung up.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What tyranny hath been exercised of late? I dare not venture on.

sp.speaker: Amo.
sp.l: Fear not my lord, our habits give us safety.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Behold, the tyrant maketh towards us.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Holy, and reverent pilgrims, welcome.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Bold strangers, by the tempest beaten in.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Most welcome still, we are but stewards for such guests as you,
What we possess is yours, to your wants due,
We are only rich for your necessities.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A generous, free, and charitable mind
Keeps in thy bosom to poor pilgrim's kind.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: 'Tis time of day to dine my friends; Sertorio?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Our food.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis ready for your highness.

div.stage: Loud music. A banquet brought in, and by it a small table for the Queen.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Sit, pray sit, religious men right welcome
Unto our cates. Grave sir I have observed
You waste the virtue of your serious eye
Too much on such a worthless objects as that is.
A traitor when he lived called that his flesh;
Let hang, here's to you, we are the oldest here,
Round let it go, feed, if you like your cheer.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Ready my lord.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Sit merry. Exit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where ere I look these limbs aren in mine eye.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Some wretch on whom he wrought his tyranny.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Hard was his fate to light into his mercy.

sp.speaker: Amorp.
sp.l: Peace, he comes.

div.stage: Soft music. Enter the tyrant with the Queen, her hair loose, she makes a curtsy to the table. Sertorio brings in the flesh with a skull all bloody, they all wonder.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: I perceive strangers more desire to see
An object than the fare before them set;
But since your eyes are serious suitors grown
I will discourse; what's seen shall now be known.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your bounty every way conquers poor strangers.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: You creature whom your eyes so often visit
Held mighty sway over our powers and thoughts,
Indeed we were all hers.
Besides her graces, there were all perfections;
Unless she speaks, no music: till her wishes
Brought forth a monster, a detested issue
Poisoning the thoughts I held of her.
sp.stage: The old King sends forth Amorpho.
sp.l: She did from her own ardour undergo
Adulterous baseness with my professed foe;
Her lust strangely betrayed, I ready to surprise them,
Set on fire by the abuse, I found his life
Cunningly shifted by her own dear hand
And far enough conveyed from my revenge:
Unnaturally she first abused my heart,
And then prevented my revenge by art.
Yet there I left not; though his trunk were cold
My wrath was flaming, and I exercised
New vengeance on his carcase; and gave charge
The body should be quartered and hung up; 'twas donē,
this as a penance I enjoined her to
To taste no other sustenance; no nor dares
Till her love's body be consumed in hers.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The sin was great, so is the penance grievous.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Our vow is signed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And was he lydian born?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: He was no less, son to mine enemy,
A banished King; Tymethes was his name.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O me, my son tymethes.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Passion may spoil us: sir, we oft have heard
Of that old King his father; and that justly
This kingdom was by right due to his sway.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: It was, I think it was, till we called in
By policy and force deceived his confidence,
Showed him a trick of war and turned him out.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sin's boast is worse than sin.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: All's sure, the guards are seized on.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The Passagē strongly guarded.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Holy sir, what's he?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Our brother, a poor pilgrim, that gives notice
Of a religious father that attends
To bear us company in our pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: O, ho, 'tis good, 'tis very good.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Alas poor lady, it makes me weep to see what food she eats.
I know your mercy will remit this penance.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Never, our vow's irrevocable, never;
The lecher must be swallowed rib by rib,
His flesh is sweet, it melts, and goes down merrily,
Ha? what aren these?

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: Speranza.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Villain, this minute loses thee, thou tyrant.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: Pilgrims wear arms? the old King? and Lapirus?
Betrayed? confounded? o, I must die forsworn;
break vow, bleed whore, there is my jealousy flown.
O happy man, 'tis more revenge to me
Then all your aims, I have killed my jealousy.
I have nothing now to care for more than hell
'T had been if you had struck me ere she fell.
I had left her to your lust, the thought is bitterness,
But she first fallen; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Die cruel murderous tyrant.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.l: So, laugh away this breath,
My lust was ne'er more pleasing than my death. Dyes.

sp.speaker: Lap.
sp.l: As full possessed as ever, and as rich
In subjects' hearts and voices; we present thee
The complete sway of this usurped kingdom.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I am so born betwixt the violent streams
Of joy and passion, I forget my state;
To all our thanks and favours, and what more
We are in debt to all your free consent
We will discharge in happy government.

div.stage: Enter the old Queen disguised, a boy with her.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: The peacefull'st reign that ever prince enjoyed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Already a petition? suitors begin betimes
We are scarce warm in our good fortune yet, what are you?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Unworthiest of all the joys this hour brings forth.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Our dearest Queen?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Your poor distressed Queen.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O let me light upon that constant breast,
And kiss thee till my soul melt on thy lips:
Our joys were perfect, stood Tymethes there,
We are old; this kingdom wants a hopeful heir.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Your joys are perfect though he stand not there,
And your wish blessed behold a hopeful heir:
Stand not amazed, 'tis Manophes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How just the gods are? who in their due time
Return what they took from us.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Happy hour,
heaven hath not taken all our happiness;
For though your elder met ill fate, good heaven
Hath thus preserved your younger for your heir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Prepare those limbs for honourable burial,
And noble nephew all your ill is lost
In your late new born goodness, which we'll reward,
No storm of fate so fierce but time destroys,
And beats back misery with a peal of joys.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
